\/D:\/repos\/stride-translations\/pt-BR\: With <g1>render textures</g1>, you can send a camera's view to a texture and use the texture on objects in your scene.
With <g1>render textures</g1>, you can send a camera's view to a texture and use the texture on objects in your scene.
For example, you can use this to display part of your scene on a TV screen in the same scene, such as security camera footage.
For example, you can use this to display part of your scene on a TV screen in the same scene, such as security camera footage.
For API details, see <g1>Textures and render textures</g1>.
For API details, see <g1>Textures and render textures</g1>.
Camera slots link the graphics compositor to the cameras in your scene.
Camera slots link the graphics compositor to the cameras in your scene.
You need to add a camera slot for a new camera to use.

in the <g1>Camera</g1> component properties, under <g2>Slot</g2>, select the slot you created in the previous step.

If you don't want the texture to be semi-transparent, under the <g1>Source</g1> properties, clear the <g2>Is transparent</g2> checkbox.

To display a render texture in your scene, you need at least two renderers:
To display a render texture in your scene, you need at least two renderers:
one to render your main camera
one to render your main camera
one to render the second camera to the render texture
one to render the second camera to the render texture
This page describes the simplest way to do this from scratch, using two cameras and two renderers.
This page describes the simplest way to do this from scratch, using two cameras and two renderers.
